awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  The Role of F-box-Mediated Protein Degradation in Seed Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Seeds are important for the propagation of flowering plants and are also the primary source of food for human and animal consumption.  Understanding the molecular mechanisms underpinning seed development can help protect plant diversity and secure the ever-increasing demand for food production.  Rapid cell division and tissue patterning during the process of seed development result in the production of various short-lived regulatory proteins that are removed in a timely manner.  Alterations to these protein removal pathways can cause sterility or a severe reduction in the quantity and quality of seed production.  However, currently little is known about the identity of these short-lived proteins and how they are targeted for removal.  The goal of this research is to understand the functions of a specific group of proteins, termed the F-box proteins, in regulating protein turnover during seed development.  The resulting discoveries can then be translated into crop breeding for developing innovative approaches to manipulate seed production.  The interdisciplinary nature of this project will provide a wide array of training opportunties for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including those from groups under-represented in science.  In addition, this project will develop and promote a "big data" - enabled educational system through classroom teaching, research mentoring in the laboratory, and outreach programs.  This training system is critical in modern biological education due to the exponential increase in genomic sequencing.  The educational goal of this project is to train diverse students, particularly those from educationally underserved Appalachian areas, to develop computational thinking skills in solving biological questions, thus empowering them to pursue a STEM-based career.

The F-box protein family serves as the substrate receptor in Skp1-Cullin 1-F-box (SCF) ubiquitin ligases that target many abnormal and short-lived proteins for ubiquitylation and subsequent degradation by the 26S proteasome.  In plants, this family plays a wide range of regulatory roles as suggested by its large expansion in plant genomes and genetic analyses of several members in the family.  Unfortunately, little is known about the functions of most F-box proteins.  Given the presence of many conserved cellular differentiation programs that coordinate to form a mature seed, the over-arching goal of this project is to uncover the role of evolutionarily-conserved F-box proteins in seed development, using Arabidopsis thaliana as a model.  First, RNA-Seq experiments and proteomic analyses will be undertaken to define the global influence of F-box-mediated protein degradation in seed development.  Bioinformatic approaches will then be used to construct dynamic regulatory networks between active F-box members, F-box substrates, and transcription factors involved in different seed developmental stages.  Second, a novel inducible clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat interference (CRISPRi) approach, combined with conventional T-DNA insertion mutations and over-expression strategies, will be used to uncover the genetic functions of conserved F-box genes in embryogenesis.  Third, comprehensive genetic, biochemical, and proteomic approaches will be utilized to fine tune the mechanistic roles of F-box proteins involved in seed development.  Fourth, the sequencing data generated from the experiments will be adopted in "big data" - enabled biological education, in which different levels of computational thinking skills will be incorporated to train a diverse group of students.  This research is anticipated to contribute in-depth knowledge to both seed biology and the biochemistry of protein ubiquitylation.  Innovative materials, methods, and algorithms created in the project will have substantial impacts on furthering the understanding of the role of protein ubiquitylation in gene expression regulation.
The Project is jointly funded by Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and Integrative Organismal Systems, with additional support provided by the Directorate's Rule of Life Venture Fund.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The major goal of this project was to characterize the functions of evolutionarily conserved F-box proteins in Arabidopsis seed development.  Although 783 F-box genes were annotated in the genome of the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, nearly 90% of them do not have a known biological function.  Through bioinformatics and evolutionary studies, we identified a group of 129 Core Arabidopsis F-box (CAF) genes, most of which are evolutionarily conserved across 111 plant genomes, ranging from one red alga as an outgroup to 9 green algae, 14 basal embryophytes, 15 Poaceae plants, 12 non-rosid dicots, 31 non-brassicale rosids, and 29 brassicales.  We demonstrated biochemically that at least 102 out of 129 CAF proteins (79%) physically interact with the Arabidopsis Skp1-Like (ASK) 1 protein to form the substrate receptor module of a Skp1-CUL1-F-box ubiquitin E3 ligase complex.  Combined with genetic, seed development, and transcriptomic analyses of a newly developed ask1 Ds-insertion null mutant, we concluded that ASK1 is a predominant Skp1 protein regulating Arabidopsis growth and development.  Given the evolutionary conservation of most CAF proteins and the predominant function of ASK1, we utilized both genetic and proteomic approaches to characterize the roles of CAFs in seed development, seed germination, and early seedling establishment.  By solving the challenges of functional redundancy of duplicated CAF genes and the lethality of constitutive F-box overexpression transgenic plants in the genetic studies, we developed a library of inducible overexpression lines for 40 CAF genes, many of which did not have known biological functions.  Through systematically analyzing the impact of conditional overexpression of these 40 CAFs on seed development, seed germination, and early seedling growth, we categorized their roles in regulating seed yield, seed germination, and seedling establishment.  We discovered that CAF overexpression during seed germination and early seedling establishment regulates root and aerial tissue growth positively and negatively, respectively.  We identified at least 15 CAFs that positively regulate radicle rupture during seed germination by compromising abscisic acid (ABA)-mediated germination suppression.  However, upregulation of these CAFs during seed development resulted in varied seed germination responses to the ABA treatment, demonstrating their developmental-dependent functional differentiation.  Using an independent biochemical and proteomic approach, we identified a set of 43 biochemically active F-box proteins that interact with ASK1 and ASK2 in vivo during early seedling growth.  Among these active F-box proteins, 32 belong to our evolutionarily characterized CAFs, thus biochemically confirming their core functions in Arabidopsis.  In addition to this global characterization of CAFs, we uncovered the molecular mechanistic functions of four CAFs, including two in seed development, one in gravity response, and one in epigenetic regulation.  Using a comprehensive biochemical study on the 26S proteasome and autophagy activities during silique development, we discovered a relay model of these two major types of protein degradation machinery in regulating silique and seed development.  

 

Broader Impacts

Our studies have made several practical and theoretical impacts that would accelerate the functional genomic studies of this largely unknown F-box gene family in plants.  Our evolutionary discovery of the deleterious duplication model of the F-box gene family in plant genomes and our proteomic and bioinformatic identification of the active F-box members provided theoretical guidance to prioritize our future focus on the functional characterization of CAF genes.  Our discovery of the relay activities between the 26S proteasome and autophagy during seed development demonstrated "an excellent example of UPS/autophagy crosstalk influencing plant development" (commented by Dr. Suayib Üstün and his colleagues, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tplants.2023.01.013).  Our newly developed inducible CRISPR interference method would be applicable to other functional characterization of essential genes in plant biology research.  The genetic materials, including the ask1 mutant and 40 CAF conditional overexpression transgenic lines, would benefit the community in studying the functions of CAF genes.  The interdisciplinary nature of this project provided a wide array of scientific approaches for diverse trainees, including one visiting scholar, one master′s and four Ph.D. graduate students, and 16 undergraduate students in the PI′s lab.  The project also developed a data-enabled pedagogy, resulting in one instructional book on genomics techniques that has been made available publicly and bioinformatics lectures and labs in one graduate course and two undergraduate courses taught by the PI annually at Ohio University.  In the funding period of this grant, the data-enabled classroom education has been exposed to 39 graduate students and 754 undergraduate students.  With the participation of the graduate and undergraduate students in the lab, we have also developed and provided four outreach programs for girls participating in Tech Savvy, visiting middle and high school students, and the public, including students on campus, residents, and visitors near uptown Athens, Ohio.

 

Publications and Products

To date, the discoveries from this project have been disseminated in 15 journal articles, one bioinformatics software package in GitHub, two RNA-seq datasets in NCBI, one instructional book, one master′s thesis, three Ph.D. dissertations, and 59 poster and oral presentations. 

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2024
Modified by: Zhihua Hua
